title: 104_hr3226
content:
The Act titled "Newborns' and Mothers' Health Protection Act of 1996" emphasizes individualized post-delivery care for mothers and newborns, considering health factors and support systems. Discharge timing should be decided by the attending provider in consultation with the mother. Required coverage for minimum hospital stay following birth is mandated. The Newborns' and Mothers' Health Protection Act of 1996 mandates coverage for a minimum of 48 hours of in-patient care after a normal vaginal delivery and 96 hours after a caesarean section for mothers and newborns under health plans, without requiring prior authorization. Exceptions exist for specific cases. The Newborns' and Mothers' Health Protection Act of 1996 requires coverage for a minimum of 48 hours after a normal delivery and 96 hours after a caesarean section for mothers and newborns under health plans. Discharge before this period is allowed if decided by the provider in consultation with the mother, with coverage for post-delivery follow-up care. SEC. 4. POST-DELIVERY FOLLOW-UP CARE. The health plan or employee health benefit plan must cover timely post-delivery care for a mother and her newborn child if discharged before 48 hours for a normal delivery or 96 hours for a caesarean section. Care can be provided by various healthcare professionals in different settings as determined by regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure coverage for timely post-delivery care, including options for care in the home. This care should be provided within 24 to 72 hours following discharge, meeting the health needs of the mother and newborn child. Regulations must also align with state laws regarding post-delivery care settings. Regulations for post-delivery care settings should align with State licensing and practice laws. SEC. 5. PROHIBITIONS. In implementing the requirements of this Act, health plans and employee health benefit plans are prohibited from denying coverage to mothers and newborns, offering incentives for less coverage, or incentivizing providers to go against the Act. Providers cannot be penalized for following the requirements of the Act. The Act prohibits health plans from denying coverage to mothers and newborns or incentivizing providers to go against it. Mothers are not required to give birth in a hospital or stay for a fixed period after childbirth. SEC. 6. NOTICE. Employee health benefit plans and health plans must provide written notice to participants and policyholders about coverage required by the Act within 120 days of enactment and annually. SEC. 7. APPLICABILITY. A requirement or standard imposed on a health plan under this Act shall be enforced by the State insurance commissioner or designated officials. This applies to health plan issuers offering plans in connection with an employee health benefit plan. The Secretary shall not enforce the requirements of this Act on health plan issuers or health plans, and States cannot enforce them on employee health benefit plans. This Act does not affect section 514 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. Each State must ensure that health plans meet the standards of this Act. Employee health benefit plans will be enforced similarly to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Civil penalties will apply for non-compliance with reporting requirements. In cases where a State fails to enforce the standards of the Act regarding health plans, the Secretary will enforce them in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Health plan issuers in non-compliant States will be subject to civil enforcement under specific sections of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Civil penalties will apply for failure to disclose required information. Regulations will be established by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, may promulgate regulations to implement the Act. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "attending provider" includes obstetrician-gynecologists, pediatricians, family physicians, and other healthcare providers responsible for the care of a mother and her newborn child. The term "beneficiary" refers to individuals as defined in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The term "employee health benefit plan" encompasses various types of health benefit plans. A health benefit plan, whether provided directly, through a health plan issuer, or otherwise, that offers health benefits for participants and beneficiaries. Employee health benefit plans are not considered health plans or issuers. Exclusions apply to certain arrangements. The curr_chunk lists different types of insurance coverage that can be included in a health benefit plan, such as accident, disability income insurance, Medicare supplemental health insurance, liability insurance, workers compensation, automobile medical payment insurance, and coverage for specified diseases or illnesses. The curr_chunk defines different types of insurance coverage that can be part of a health benefit plan, including hospital indemnity, short-term insurance, dental-only, vision-only, and long-term care insurance. A group purchaser is defined as a person or entity that buys health benefits for participants or beneficiaries. The curr_chunk explains that a health plan can be a group health plan or an individual health plan, which provide or pay for health benefits in connection with an employee health benefit plan. The curr_chunk defines a plan issuer that provides health benefits but is not a group health plan. It excludes certain types of coverage like accident insurance, Medicare supplemental insurance, liability insurance supplements, and general liability insurance. The curr_chunk lists various types of insurance coverage that are included in the definition of a plan issuer providing health benefits, such as workers compensation, automobile medical payment, specified disease, hospital indemnity, short-term limited duration, and long-term care insurance. The curr_chunk defines terms related to health plan issuers, participants, and the Secretary of Labor. SEC. 10. PREEMPTION.

This Act does not override State laws mandating minimum in-patient care for normal vaginal deliveries and caesarean sections, as well as guidelines for maternity and pediatric care. Follow-up care must also align with this Act.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. The provisions of this Act apply to health plans starting January 1, 1997, and to employee health benefit plans on the first day of the first plan year beginning on or after January 1, 1997.
